name: Dali
title: Dali - Traveling China like your home yard
overview: Dali, nestled in the western reaches of Yunnan Province, presents one of China's most idyllic landscapes, where the crystal-clear waters of Erhai Lake meet the imposing Cangshan Mountains. This ancient city, which served as the capital of the Nanzhao and Dali Kingdoms from the 8th to 13th centuries, carries a legacy of over a thousand years of continuous habitation. The city's unique location on a narrow strip of land between the 40-kilometer-long lake and the 19-peak mountain range creates a dramatic natural setting that has inspired poets, painters, and travelers for generations. The heart of Dali is its ancient town, a walled settlement that preserves the traditional architecture of the Bai ethnic minority. Unlike many tourist-oriented ancient towns in China, Dali's old city maintains an authentic, lived-in atmosphere where locals continue their daily routines alongside the cafes, guesthouses, and artisan shops that cater to visitors. The Bai people, known for their distinctive white-washed walls, upturned eaves, and intricate woodcarvings, have created a built environment that harmonizes perfectly with the natural surroundings. The iconic Three Pagodas of Chongsheng Temple, standing for over a millennium, serve as silent sentinels watching over the valley. Beyond the ancient town, Dali offers a lifestyle that has made it a magnet for Chinese and international expatriates seeking an alternative to urban pressures. The mild climate, with temperatures rarely exceeding 30°C even in summer, supports a year-round growing season that fills local markets with fresh produce. Cycling around Erhai Lake has become a rite of passage for visitors, passing through fishing villages, wetlands, and farmland where traditional methods persist. The Dali lifestyle emphasizes slow living, artistic expression, and connection with nature—values increasingly rare in modern China. Whether you're exploring the marble workshops that give Dali its name ('da' meaning marble), sampling Bai minority cuisine, or simply watching the clouds roll over Cangshan Mountain, Dali offers a glimpse into a more measured, beautiful way of life.

gettingAround: Bicycle: Popular way to explore Erhai Lake and surrounding areas
Taxi: Available for short distances within the city
Bus: Local bus services to major attractions
Walking: Best way to explore Dali Ancient Town
